text: "We still have to pay a lot more attention to how sexual harassment and assault affect the most vulnerable and marginalized women and not just high-profile, typically white, beautiful Hollywood actresses," @kate_manne says. https://t.co/g1p73IIOr2

name: NewYorker
text: What unites Jessica Krug’s various adopted identities is her affinity for Blackness as an instrument of authenticity as she made her way through academia. https://t.co/K0AsrJKLUW

name: NewYorker
text:
The best-selling writer Susanna Clarke, whose novel “Jonathan Strange & Mr. Norrell” is set in an alternative version of England during the Regency period, says she feels more at home in the 19th century than she does in the present. 
https://t.co/CvZDjr62bY

text: “whose books? | whose books / did you burn? | / reader, I burnt yours.” A poem by Simon Armitage. https://t.co/dz4LyzKc1g

text: A panic in the sugar industry—over new nutrition standards, regulatory pressure, and public sentiment—has prompted a race to not just develop a substitute, but to design a better sugar altogether. https://t.co/ErCluO4BA4

text: The coronavirus has revealed to many the geography of class in America, showing that where we live and work shapes whether we live or die. Might it offer a similar lesson about where we learn? https://t.co/gTNFjSOlZJ

text: Carefully balanced rock towers make a pretty picture, but the proliferation of cairns, fuelled by social media, has negative consequences for the environment. https://t.co/WkkVsXU9Oi

text: Calvin Tomkins on the many delights of the artist Pipilotti Rist’s videos. “What Rist delivers in abundance is pleasure, something that has been out of bounds in contemporary art since the 1970s.” https://t.co/4xLonEqI9W

text: At President Trump's campaign rallies, the mood remains exuberant, despite the new state of public-health emergency, economic crisis, and popular protest. https://t.co/u24uyAGI6w
